title: Chronic Cervicogenic Headache in an Office Worker
clinical_history: David is a 42-year-old marketing executive who presents with a 5-month history of persistent headaches, primarily felt at the back of the head and upper neck, sometimes radiating to the temples and behind the eyes. The pain is described as a dull, aching pressure with intermittent sharp exacerbations. He reports that the headaches typically intensify after prolonged computer work and are often worse towards the end of the workday. David notes associated neck stiffness and occasional mild dizziness, but denies visual changes, nausea, or photophobia. He does not recall any recent trauma but admits to poor posture at his desk and increasing work-related stress. Over-the-counter analgesics provide only temporary relief.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged sitting at a desk, poor ergonomics, extended periods of computer use, stress, sudden neck movements
picture: Illustration of pain distribution: suboccipital area, spreading to temples and behind the eyes
easing_factors: Short breaks with neck stretches, massage of neck muscles, improved posture, heat application, lying down in a dark quiet room
past_history: History of episodic tension-type headaches during university years; no previous neck injuries; no history of migraine.
medical_history: No chronic illnesses; non-smoker; moderate intake of caffeine (2-3 cups coffee/day); BMI 27.
medications: Occasional use of ibuprofen (200-400 mg) for headache relief, with partial effect.
personal_history: Lives with his spouse and two children. Works 50+ hours per week; sedentary lifestyle; reports increased workload and stress over the last year; does not engage in regular physical activity.
imaging: Not performed to date; patient exhibits no red flag symptoms warranting immediate imaging.
